G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31, 31A an.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A and 37, and G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6, as this is a domestic relations matter involving custody and parenting time of minor children previously adjudicated by this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A and 37, and G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6, as this is a domestic relations matter involving custody and parenting time of minor children previously adjudicated by this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting time judgment upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting time judgment upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The paramount concern of the Court in custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount concern of the Court in custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses and reaffirms that custody determinations are governed by the “best interests of the child” standard and describes that the child’s best interests are the paramount concern in such cases. The court traces the historical development of the best-interests standard, cites prior Massachusetts cases using the same formulation, and applies that standard to resolve the custody dispute, making it clear that this is the controlling and paramount consideration in custody and parenting time decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)….”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The paramount concern of the Court in custody and parenting time determinations is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the issue as how domestic violence must be taken into account in custody determinations and explicitly ties that to considering the 'best interests of the child,' including by referencing and applying G.L. c. 208, § 31. While the main holding is about requiring explicit findings on the effects of domestic violence, that requirement is grounded in ensuring custody decisions reflect the child’s best interests. The case thus implicitly affirms that the paramount concern in custody determinations is the child’s best interests, though it is not a leading articulation of that general principle.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court’s remand order is designed to do just that. We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm. … The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that… the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to modify custody and parenting time arrangements to protect the safety and welfare of minor children when circumstances have changed. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to modify custody and parenting time arrangements to protect the safety and welfare of minor children when circumstances have changed. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to modify custody and parenting time arrangements to protect the safety and welfare of minor children when circumstances have changed. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits of a Probate and Family Court judge’s authority to order a custodial, unmarried mother to relocate back to Massachusetts. It does not discuss or invoke the court’s broad equitable authority under G.L. c. 215, § 6 or c. 208, §§ 28, 31, nor does it frame any modification of custody/parenting time as an exercise of such broad equitable powers to protect child safety and welfare. Instead, it constrains the judge’s authority in this context and treats the case as a routine custody/visitation matter governed narrowly by G.L. c. 209C, § 10.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights. See G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), (b).”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to modify custody and parenting time arrangements to protect the safety and welfare of minor children when circumstances have changed. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection/guardianship jurisdiction and standards case, not a modification-of-custody case under the cited domestic relations statutes. It emphasizes parental fitness, standards of proof, and proper procedural vehicle (Probate and Family Court guardianship) and reverses the custody order; it does not discuss broad equitable authority to modify existing custody/parenting time upon changed circumstances under G.L. c. 215, § 6 or G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31. Thus it does not support the specific proposition about broad equitable modification power in response to changed circumstances.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “Unless proceedings involving the custody of a minor are expedited, they fail to accomplish their purpose. Circumstances may change rapidly, and the harm sought to be avoided may worsen with the passage of time. Here, the child was nine years old when the petition was filed. She is now twelve years old. Prompt resolution of custody issues is essential.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: In determining best interests, the Court may and should consider evidence of domestic violence, abuse, or a pattern of coercive, controlling, or intimidating behavior in the child’s environment, including the conduct of a parent’s current or former partner. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; G.L. c. 209A; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: In determining best interests, the Court may and should consider evidence of domestic violence, abuse, or a pattern of coercive, controlling, or intimidating behavior in the child’s environment, including the conduct of a parent’s current or former partner. See G.L. c. 208, § 31A; G.L. c. 209A; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Court may impose conditions on parenting time, including supervised visitation and restrictions on the presence of certain third parties, when necessary to protect a child’s physical and emotional well‑being. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of Hugo concerns competing adoption plans (aunt vs. foster mother) and the best‑interests analysis in selecting among them. It does not address visitation or parenting‑time conditions, supervised contact, or restrictions on third‑party presence, nor does it interpret G.L. c. 208, § 28 (a divorce/parenting‑time statute, not applied here). Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about imposing conditions on parenting time or supervised visitation.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The 'best interests of a child' is a question that presents the trial judge 'with a classic example of a discretionary decision.'"

M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).proposition: The Court may impose conditions on parenting time, including supervised visitation and restrictions on the presence of certain third parties, when necessary to protect a child’s physical and emotional well‑being. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: This opinion is about child support calculation between never‑married parents with shared physical custody and high incomes. It does not address parenting time conditions, supervised visitation, or restrictions on third parties. Nothing in the holding or reasoning concerns imposing conditions on visitation to protect a child’s well‑being, so the case does not support the cited proposition for that purpose.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).relevant_excerpt: We are asked to address whether, and in what amount, child support may be ordered with respect to parents who never married, but who share legal and physical custody of their child, enjoy comparable standards of living, and have incomes that exceed the levels to which the Massachusetts Child Support Guidelines presumptively apply.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Court may impose conditions on parenting time, including supervised visitation and restrictions on the presence of certain third parties, when necessary to protect a child’s physical and emotional well‑being. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: This opinion is about relocation and modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, not about imposing conditions such as supervised parenting time or restricting third parties. The court reverses a change of custody and allows relocation, and at the end merely notes that on remand the Probate Court may set “time and conditions of visitation,” but it does not discuss or endorse supervised visitation or third‑party restrictions as protective measures. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “The judgment denying removal and awarding custody to the father is reversed. We remand for the entry of a judgment that the custody of the parties’ minor child remain with the mother, that she may relocate with the child to Rhode Island, ‘and for such further proceedings consistent with this opinion relative to time and conditions of visitation.’ Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. at 558.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595\u201.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions recognize that exposure of children to domestic conflict, violence, or threatening or volatile behavior within a household may justify a modification of custody or parenting time, even where the children are not the direct targets of physical abuse, when such exposure compromises their safety or emotional development. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–597; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–848; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225–227; Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass. 333 (2005); Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 492 (1991).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845\u20138.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions recognize that exposure of children to domestic conflict, violence, or threatening or volatile behavior within a household may justify a modification of custody or parenting time, even where the children are not the direct targets of physical abuse, when such exposure compromises their safety or emotional development. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–597; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–848; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225–227; Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass. 333 (2005); Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 492 (1991).

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225\u2013.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions recognize that exposure of children to domestic conflict, violence, or threatening or volatile behavior within a household may justify a modification of custody or parenting time, even where the children are not the direct targets of physical abuse, when such exposure compromises their safety or emotional development. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–597; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–848; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225–227; Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass. 333 (2005); Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 492 (1991).

Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions recognize that exposure of children to domestic conflict, violence, or threatening or volatile behavior within a household may justify a modification of custody or parenting time, even where the children are not the direct targets of physical abuse, when such exposure compromises their safety or emotional development. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–597; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–848; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225–227; Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass. 333 (2005); Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 492 (1991).
Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion is focused on procedural standards for emergency and temporary custody under G.L. c. 119 §§ 24–25 (sufficiency of care and protection petitions and availability of hearings). It does not discuss domestic conflict, domestic violence, or children’s exposure to threatening or volatile household behavior as a basis for modifying custody or parenting time. The citation to Care & Protection of Lillian for that specific domestic-violence-related proposition is therefore not supported by this text.
Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The purpose of G. L. c. 119 is to protect children ‘against the harmful effects resulting from the absence, inability, inadequacy or destructive behavior of parents or parent substitutes.’ G. L. c. 119, § 1. A petition for care and protection may be filed when a person alleges that a child’s situation falls under one of four concerns enumerated in G. L. c. 119, § 24… We conclude that a petition is sufficient if it alleges specific facts… that, if true, fall within at least one of those four enumerated concerns.”

Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 49.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions recognize that exposure of children to domestic conflict, violence, or threatening or volatile behavior within a household may justify a modification of custody or parenting time, even where the children are not the direct targets of physical abuse, when such exposure compromises their safety or emotional development. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–597; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–848; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 225–227; Care & Protection of Lillian, 445 Mass. 333 (2005); Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 492 (1991).
Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 49.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a care and protection proceeding focused on the mother’s mental illness, substance abuse, and general parental unfitness. While it briefly notes an incident where the mother’s boyfriend beat her and the child was apparently habituated to this chaotic lifestyle, the court does not analyze or articulate any legal principle that exposure to domestic conflict or violence (as opposed to direct abuse or overall neglectful environment) justifies modification of custody or parenting time. The holding is about admissibility of evidence and the non‑application of the exclusionary rule in care and protection cases, not about domestic violence as a basis for changing custody or visitation.
Care & Protection of Frank, 409 Mass. 49.relevant_excerpt: The report states that the mother was bleeding from the mouth when the officers arrived at 11:30 p.m. It further states that the mother was heavily intoxicated, and that she yelled and cursed continuously. The report describes the apartment as “a complete mess,” with cigarettes and beer cans strewn about. In addition, the reporting officer notes that Frank “in my opinion was able to sleep through [the incident] as he is use [szc] to this type of life style.” … Even if the report contains evidence of the mother’s criminal conduct, however, because it contains evidence of the officer’s personal observations which are relevant to the issue of parental fitness, the admission of the report was not in error.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31, 31A.proposition: Related statutory provisions: G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A; G.L. c. 209A; G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 6.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: Related statutory provisions: G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A; G.L. c. 209A; G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 6.
